image.altText: Francene Jacques, with shoulder-length brown hair and wearing glasses and and pink cardigan, smiles slightly.

items.synopsis: With reports of elder abuse on the rise in Australia, these women in their 80s are sharing their stories in the hope that others seek the help they need.

title.children: The small acts of violence that led 81-year-old Francene to understand she was experiencing elder abuse

image.altText: A toddler strapped into a pram.

items.synopsis: A man has been charged with the murder of 17-month-old toddler Ronan Davies, who was rushed to Adelaide's Women's and Children's Hospital but died two days later.

title.children: Man charged with murder of 17-month-old toddler Ronan Davies

image.altText: A serious-looking Chinese woman in a blue suit stands at a podium and gestures with her hand.

items.synopsis: Australian citizen and legal scholar Kevin Yam, and former Hong Kong politician Ted Hui, who fled the island and now lives in Adelaide, are among eight people wanted for alleged breaches under the controversial National Security Law.

title.children: China tells Australia to stop harbouring 'fugitives', DFAT updates Hong Kong travel advice over security law

image.altText: woman standing looking down barrel holding baby boy, she has brown hair and is wearing glasses, baby has big blue eyes

items.synopsis: Home owners are struggling with increasing repayments amid reports that regional house prices have stagnated, despite interest rates staying on hold on Tuesday.

title.children: 'We've gone backwards': Young family sells home because they can't afford repayments, interest rate pause no help

image.altText: Two images next to each other, one a shiraz grape bunch on the vine, the other a canola flower in the field.

items.synopsis: WA is famous for wines produced in the Margaret River and Great Southern regions but hidden within the canola fields of the Wheatbelt is an unusual vineyard.

title.children: The Wheatbelt isn't known for wine, but one vineyard is thriving against the odds

image.altText: A woman wearing pink pulling gym equipment

items.synopsis: A world-first study from Australian researchers has found the likely reason why breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy commonly experience reduced cognitive function.

title.children: Deirdre's brain fog was so bad she forgot what day it was. Scientists now know why

image.altText: An illustration of artists JK-47, Alex Lahey and Sarah Blasko

items.synopsis: More than 840 cover songs have been played in the triple j studios across 20 years. The data shows us how artists craft a cover song.

title.children: Some of the world's biggest songs are covers. What makes a good one?

image.altText: A close up of a smiling woman wearing a traditional dress on a Bhutanese square.

items.synopsis: After centuries of isolation, Bhutan opened its doors to tourism in the 1970s. But when the ABC was granted rare entry into the country, it found a nation losing a high proportion of people — mainly to Australia.

title.children: 'It feels so empty': The forbidden kingdom of Bhutan is turning into a ghost town

image.altText: Philip Lowe sitting at a desk behind a microphone mid-sentence, gesturing with his right hand and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Australian home borrowers are experiencing much, much more interest rate pain than borrowers in New Zealand, Canada, the UK or US – for one simple reason, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: The simple reason why Australian mortgage borrowers are in more pain than those in other countries

image.altText: Jake sits in a chair while receiving treatment

items.synopsis: Jake Usher wants you to talk about poo, and not for frivolous reasons. Last year, at the age of 31, he was diagnosed with stage 4 bowel cancer.

title.children: Jake thought bowel cancer was an old person's disease — until he was diagnosed

image.altText: A woman smiles as her two small children sit at the top of a slide.

items.synopsis: Numerous studies show universal early childhood education provides a huge boost to the economy. The federal government is currently determining whether it will be introduced in Australia.

title.children: Studies show universal child care would result in sizeable boost to Australia's economy. So why don't we have it?

image.altText: A composite of Ash Barty and her newborn baby.

items.synopsis: Former world number one tennis player Ash Barty announces the birth of her first child, Hayden.

title.children: 'Our beautiful boy': Australian tennis great Ash Barty gives birth to son

image.altText: A flat white drone with four rotors in flight with trees in the background.

items.synopsis: The Defence Department, police and border agents have grounded DJI drones over security concerns, but questioning from one senator has confirmed the devices are still used widely across government.

title.children: DJI drones in wide use across government departments despite defence, Border Force bans

image.altText: Rene Caris handballs for Geelong

items.synopsis: Rene Caris admitted to feeling a little gun-shy when she returned from a mandatory two-week lay-off with concussion. Now, Heather Anderson's CTE diagnosis has put those concerns into sharp focus.

title.children: Concussion concerns aired as professional footballers head into finals following landmark CTE ruling

image.altText: Two professional cricket players speak to each other on a pitch.

items.synopsis: English cricketers bristle at suggestions they have had a "Bazbawl" over the second Test, as former captain Joe Root says any suggestion Jonny Bairstow has tried for the same stumping as Alex Carey is incorrect.

title.children: Root attacks Australia, as Head claims Bairstow threatened to attempt identical dismisal

image.altText: Nusantara presentation in Singapore

items.synopsis: Joko Widodo heads home from Sydney with a promise of more assistance from Australia towards his legacy plan of building a new capital city on the island of Borneo.

title.children: Indonesia's 'clean, green, high-tech' new capital city is proving hard to sell to private investors around the world

image.altText: A yellow Ray White sign that says "lease" in front of a freestanding home.

items.synopsis: Australia's housing crisis continues as rents increase again over the June quarter. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Rents rise and there are fears of a recession if the RBA raises rates again, ASX loses ground

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened lower after a quiet night on overseas markets with Wall Street closed for the US Independence Day holiday. The ASX 200 is down one fifth of a percent in the first 15 minutes of trade. Nearly all sectors are lower with education stocks, industrials and real estate leading the falls. Bellevue Gold (+5.2 per cent) is doing the best, while Graincorp (-3.6 per cent) is doing the worst.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian share market in the red in early trade

children.content: The Australian share market has opened lower after a quiet night on overseas markets with Wall Street closed for the US Independence Day holiday.
The ASX 200 is down one fifth of a percent in the first 15 minutes of trade.
Nearly all sectors are lower with education stocks, industrials and real estate leading the falls.
Bellevue Gold (+5.2 per cent) is doing the best, while Graincorp (-3.6 per cent) is doing the worst.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A review by the corporate regulator, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, has found First Nations bank customers are paying up to $3000 in overdraw fees a year. The review looked at the cost of high fee and low fee transaction accounts offered by some of Australia's major and regional banks. It found that many Indigenous customers were in high fee accounts, despite being eligible for a low fee basic account. More than 110,000 customers in areas with a higher than average proportion of Indigenous people and receiving AbStudy payments (a living allowance for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students) were in high fee accounts. These customers paid more than $6 million in fees annually, which could have been avoided if they were in a low fee account. ASIC commissioner Danielle Press says the regulator has written to banks telling them to switch customers to cheaper accounts, and improve the situation for Indigenous customers. "Current processes to transfer eligible customers to low-fee accounts are overwhelmingly ineffective." "We are asking banks when they will migrate eligible customers to low-fee accounts, and whether they will remediate impacted customers." " We are also asking what changes will be made to ensure tailored Indigenous services are effective." " We will be monitoring these issues to ensure changes are made and will prepare a report on this project later in 2023." The review found that banks knew there were a high number of customers that were eligible for low fee accounts, but they did little to transfer them to cheaper accounts with switching rates for most banks between 0.5 per cent to 3 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: First Nations people pay $3000 annually in overdraw fees

children.content: A review by the corporate regulator, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, has found First Nations bank customers are paying up to $3000 in overdraw fees a year.
The review looked at the cost of high fee and low fee transaction accounts offered by some of Australia's major and regional banks.
It found that many Indigenous customers were in high fee accounts, despite being eligible for a low fee basic account.

More than 110,000 customers in areas with a higher than average proportion of Indigenous people and receiving AbStudy payments (a living allowance for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students) were in high fee accounts.
These customers paid more than $6 million in fees annually, which could have been avoided if they were in a low fee account.
ASIC commissioner Danielle Press says the regulator
has written to banks telling them to switch customers to cheaper accounts, and improve the situation for Indigenous customers.
"Current processes to transfer eligible customers to low-fee accounts are overwhelmingly ineffective."
"We are asking banks when they will migrate eligible customers to low-fee accounts, and whether they will remediate impacted customers."
" We are also asking what changes will be made to ensure tailored Indigenous services are effective."
" We will be monitoring these issues to ensure changes are made and will prepare a report on this project later in 2023."

The review found that banks knew there were a high number of customers that were eligible for low fee accounts, but they did little to transfer them to cheaper accounts with switching rates for most banks between 0.5 per cent to 3 per cent.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More signs the economy is slowing down. The Australian Industry Group's Australian Industry Index continued to contract in June, down 1.1 per cent to -11.9 points. Employment, industrial activity and new orders continued to pull back and head towards contraction. Meanwhile, the manufacturing industry contracted further led by the chemicals industry. Ai Group chief executive Innes Willox says Australian industry continues to struggle with weakening economic conditions. "While consumer inflation in Australia has now peaked, pricing indicators show that upwards price pressure for inputs and wages remains for industry. " "The weak employment indicator is a particular concern, coming at a time when the national economy is slowing, unemployment is creeping up, and industry is adapting to increasingly worsening conditions." " The decision by the Reserve Bank to leave interest rates unchanged reflects this slowing environment and will provide some relief for the industrial sector and households."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Industries continue to contract

children.content: More signs the economy is slowing down.
The Australian Industry Group's Australian Industry Index continued to contract in June, down 1.1 per cent to -11.9 points.
Employment, industrial activity and new orders continued to pull back and head towards contraction.
Meanwhile, the manufacturing industry contracted further led by the chemicals industry.

props.alt: Table showing contraction in Australian industry

children.content: Industry slowdown
(Ai Group)
Ai Group chief executive Innes Willox says Australian industry continues to struggle with weakening economic conditions.
"While consumer inflation in Australia has now peaked, pricing indicators show that upwards price pressure for inputs and wages remains for industry. "

"The weak employment indicator is a particular concern, coming at a time when the national economy is slowing, unemployment is creeping up, and industry is adapting to increasingly worsening conditions."
" The decision by the Reserve Bank to leave interest rates unchanged reflects this slowing environment and will provide some relief for the industrial sector and households."

image.altText: A young woman with pink hair faces news microphones with two people in dark clothes behind her.

items.synopsis: A Perth family is desperate for answers after their one-year-old daughter died days after they say she was sent home by a GP. WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that this article contains an image of a person who has died, used with the permission of their family.
